General course objectives:
General course objectives
The main goal of the course is to provide the students with an understanding and a portfolio of actionable tools (techniques) for the optimization of manufacturing processes.
The achievement of the objective is based on acquisition of data (both experimental and simulation) and the corresponding analytics to extract knowledge from those data.
Specifically, the course will integrate three main domains of data, analytics, and digital manufacturing:
(1) Multi-physics process simulation (model-driven simulation, e.g., finite element methods, computational fluid dynamics as well analytical solutions from simplified systems).
(2) Statistical modelling (data-driven simulation, e.g., design of experiments, multivariate analysis, machine learning).
(3) Digital twin technology (integration of physical data and simulative data).
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Describe the most important approaches and methods used within digitalization of manufacturing processes and production.
Manage and analyze data (both off-line and in-line) generated during manufacturing to extract insight and valuable information for effective decision making cross the entire data value chain including: (i) Data pre-setting; (ii) Data processing; (iii) Data post-process; (iv) Data quality.
Identify and apply the most relevant 1st principles-based modelling techniques for the simulation and optimization of a given manufacturing process.
Identify and apply the most relevant data-driven modelling techniques for the simulation and optimization of a given manufacturing process.
Explain product/process causalities and correlations based on (a) materials science and material behavior understanding; (b) manufacturing knowledge; (c) data analytics.
Distinguish and discuss the differences between 'correlation' and 'causality'.
Recommend optimization strategies to improve the performance of single manufacturing processes as well as process chains based on experimental and simulative data.
Use Reduced Order Models (ROMs).
Content: General digital tools for analysis of manufacturing processes with special focus on additive manufacturing and injection moulding. Classification of data including off-line data, in-line data, experimental data and observational data. Data processing and data quality. Data-driven models. Correlation and causation. 1st principles models for injection moulding and additive manufacturing for description of temperatures, material flow as well stresses and deformations. Simple analytical solutions and numerical solutions. Reduced Order Models (ROMs) based on both experimental data, observational data as well as simulated data. Optimization of manufacturing processes based on ROMs.
